author: ralexstokes
content: I suppose it depends on what we mean by “validator” and “smart wallet” — today, a validator is a BLS keypair; there is work to allow signatures to be computed under MPC to allow, e.g. decentralized staking pools

author: ralexstokes
content: We could think about moving more of the validator logic on-chain once there is an execution scheme reachable from the beacon chain but in the near term we won’t have that

author: djrtwo
content:
by owned, maybe you mean the withdrawal of funds going to a smart contract. Right now no, the withdrawal creds (version 0x00) are a bls pubkey that will sign where funds go at withdrawal. 
There is active discussion of making a version 0x01 that is an eth1addr and can thus be a smart contract

author: sky.cactus
content: Ideally, validators could be smart wallets directly.  As an example, maybe I have a 2 of 3 multisig wallet for validation so I can run 3 different clients and then only sign if all agree.

author: sky.cactus
content: So when I submit my validation, it would go through a contract, and the contract is what would be making the assertion.  What specifically the wallet requires will vary by wallet, but it could be anything from recoverable wallet, social recovery wallet, multisig, combination of the above, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: Limiting only to BLS key means that I am limited in the ways I can secure my account, and securing a high value account that is automatically executing code is hard.

author: sky.cactus
content: I am guessing  the issue is that the contract executes as part of a block, and the validation process doesn't have an EVM associated with it to process contracts?

author: protolambda
content: With BLS various schemes to do multi-sig like validation are possible. See the ongoing secret-shared-validator work. And similarly for withdrawals, the key can be split

author: sky.cactus
content: Multisig was just an example, what I really want is a recoverable wallet.

author: sky.cactus
content: That way I don't need to worry so much about destruction of my signing key.  I could store it ephemerally in a secure execution context for example, and if the box goes down I can recover access via the contract.

author: ralexstokes
content: do you have an example of a set of contracts implementing a "recoverable wallet"?

author: ralexstokes
content: what comes to mind if some kind of shamir secret sharing w/ your base secret, e.g. the one used to seed a HD key tree

author: ralexstokes
content: from there we have BLS EIPs to generate certain keys for withdrawal/signing in an eth2 validator context
